metadata.titleEn: Daily cloud-free snow composite products from MODIS Terra-Aqua and IMS for the Tibetan Plateau (2004-2013)
metadata.description: In this study, an algorithm that combines MODIS Terra and Aqua (500 m) and the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS) (4 km) is presented to provide a daily cloud-free snow-cover product (500 m), namely Terra-Aqua-IMS (TAI). The overall accuracy of the new TAI is 92.3% as compared with ground stations in all-sky conditions; this value is significantly higher than the 63.1% of the blended MODIS Terra-Aqua product and the 54.6% and 49% of the original MODIS Terra and Aqua products, respectively. Without the IMS, the daily combination of MODIS Terra-Aqua over the Tibetan Plateau (TP) can only remove limited cloud contamination: 37.3% of the annual mean cloud coverage compared with the 46.6% (MODIS Terra) and 55.1% (MODIS Aqua). The resulting annual mean snow cover over the TP from the daily TAI data is 19.1%, which is similar to the 20.6% obtained from the 8-day MODIS Terra product (MOD10A2) but much larger than the 8.1% from the daily blended MODIS Terra-Aqua product due to the cloud blockage.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) has a mean elevation of more than 4000 m above sea level, based on the area of the plateau above 2500 m (3 ×106 km2). The TP and surrounding regions have a glacial and perennial-snow area of ∼100 000 km2 comprising 46 000 glaciers. The TP is also known as Asia’s water tower because the melt-water from the glaciers and snow cover supplies Asia’s largest rivers, which sustain the domestic water supply for more than 1 billion people downstream. Snow plays an important role in the water budgets of high-mountain regions worldwide. Snow-covered area (SCA) is also one of the key variables affecting the Earth’s energy balance because of its high albedo. Snow cover has been mapped using many remote sensors in the visible, near-infrared, thermal, and microwave wavelengths. Optical remote sensing has achieved critically important data for observing the Earth’s snow cover. Since 1966, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has provided the earliest available SCA data of the Northern Hemisphere (NH). In addition, reliable hemispheric snow cover maps have been available since 1972 from NOAA’s Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) sensors. The low temporal resolution (16 days) of Landsat data hinders its wide application in snow monitoring. Available since 2000, the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) images are superior to either Landsat, due to higher temporal resolution, or AVHRR, due to higher spatial resolution and data quality in mapping SCA. However, cloud blockage greatly limits the application of these optical snow cover products. Passive microwave sensors can penetrate cloud cover and provide cloud-free snow cover products. The Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS) utilizes a variety of multi-sourced data sets, including visible imagery from geostationary satellites and polar orbiting satellites that include passive microwave sensors. However, the coarse spatial resolution of passive microwave snow products relative to moderate- and high-resolution MODIS and Landsat images is a disadvantage. Many studies have presented improved methodologies to reduce cloud obscuration and expose more snow cover pixels in the MODIS snow cover product.
research objective: In this paper, we present an algorithm, Terra–Aqua–IMS (TAI), which combines MODIS Terra and Aqua (500 m) and the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS; 4 km) to produce a daily cloud-free snow cover product (500 m). The performance of TAI is evaluated with the station-based snow depth measurements. The TP is divided into 12 great basins to compare the performance of snow cover mapping from different products.
challenges: However, cloud blockage greatly limits the application of these optical snow cover products. The low temporal resolution (16 days) of Landsat data hinders its wide application in snow monitoring. Cloud obscuration in MODIS Terra–Aqua is still a challenge. The IMS could overestimate SCA due to poor identification of fractal snow cover. The daily composite products could produce data gaps and errors due to the different viewing geometries of MODIS Terra/Aqua.
methods: The first combination is to produce daily merged Terra–Aqua images based on daily MODIS Aqua and Terra snow products, using a priority scheme. The second combination is to produce a daily combined Terra–Aqua–IMS (TAI). The IMS data are resampled from 4 km to 500 m to integrate the daily blended MODIS Terra–Aqua. The composite rule is that the remaining cloud pixels (code 50) of Terra–Aqua images are replaced with IMS pixel values and then remapped to MODIS value codes. The snow accuracies of MODIS snow products in clear-sky and all-sky conditions at the snow depth of ≥1 cm are evaluated.
dataset: For this study, daily in situ measurements of snow depth from 105 China Meteorological Data (CMA) climate stations between 2001 and 2010 are obtained from the CMA Sharing Service System. In this paper, daily MODIS Terra/Aqua (MOD10A1/ MYD10A1; MODIS Terra/Aqua Snow Cover Daily L3 Global 500 m SIN GRID V005) and 8-day MODIS Terra (MOD10A2) over 2001–2013 are acquired. The IMS snow cover images (4-km resolution and 6144 by 6144 grid) are downloaded and used in this study.
findings: The overall accuracy of the new TAI over the TP is 94% as compared with ground stations in all-sky conditions; this value is significantly higher than the 64% of the blended MODIS Terra–Aqua product and the 55% and 50% of the original MODIS Terra and Aqua products, respectively. The resulting annual mean snow cover over the TP from the daily TAI data is 19.1%, which is much larger than the 4.7%–8.1% from the daily original MODIS Terra/Aqua and the blended Terra–Aqua snow product due to cloud blockage.

Definition.Question: What is 'cloud-free snow cover product' in the context of remote sensing and snow mapping?
Definition.Answer: A cloud-free snow cover product refers to a snow mapping technology that eliminates the issue of cloud obstruction in optical remote sensing data, allowing for continuous and unobstructed observation of snow cover. This is achieved by combining data from different sources, such as MODIS Terra/Aqua and IMS, and applying algorithms to remove cloud coverage and improve snow cover mapping accuracy.

Definition.Question: What does 'resampling' mean when integrating data from different resolutions in remote sensing?
Definition.Answer: Resampling in remote sensing involves adjusting data from one spatial resolution to match the spatial resolution of another dataset. In the context of integrating IMS data (4 km resolution) with MODIS Terra-Aqua data (500 m resolution), resampling is used to allow both datasets to be combined effectively, aligning the IMS data to the higher resolution of the MODIS data.

Comparison.Question: How does the Terra–Aqua–IMS (TAI) algorithm's approach to removing cloud cover in snow products compare to traditional optical remote sensing methods?
Comparison.Answer: The TAI algorithm combines MODIS Terra and Aqua with IMS data to create a daily cloud-free snow cover product, effectively removing cloud blockage. Traditional optical remote sensing methods, like those using MODIS alone, are limited by cloud blockage, which the TAI algorithm overcomes by incorporating IMS data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the spatial resolutions of MODIS and IMS datasets impact their effectiveness in mapping snow cover on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS offers a higher spatial resolution (500 m) compared to IMS (4 km), which allows for more detailed snow cover mapping. However, IMS can penetrate cloud cover, which MODIS cannot, making IMS advantageous for ensuring cloud-free data, though at a coarser resolution.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in snow cover accuracy between the TAI product and the original MODIS Terra/Aqua products under all-sky conditions?
Comparison.Answer: The TAI product achieves an overall accuracy of 94% in all-sky conditions, significantly higher than the original MODIS Terra (55%) and Aqua (50%) products. This improvement is primarily due to the integration of IMS data, which mitigates the cloud blockage affecting MODIS products.

Interpretation.Question: What techniques could be inferred for improving cloud-free snow cover mapping in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: A potential approach involves integrating MODIS Terra and Aqua data with IMS data to produce a daily cloud-free snow cover product. This method addresses the challenge of cloud blockage by using a priority scheme to merge Terra and Aqua images and replacing remaining cloud pixels with IMS pixel values, offering a high-resolution output.

Interpretation.Question: How might researchers address the challenges of low temporal resolution in datasets when monitoring snow cover in large geographical areas?
Interpretation.Answer: By utilizing datasets like MODIS, which offers higher temporal resolution compared to Landsat, and integrating them with other sources such as IMS, researchers can overcome temporal resolution limitations. The combination of multiple data sources can help fill data gaps and provide more frequent monitoring of snow cover despite inherent challenges like cloud blockage.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred for validating snow cover datasets against ground-truth measurements in challenging terrains?
Interpretation.Answer: One could infer the use of ground-based snow depth measurements from climate stations, as demonstrated by the comparison of snow cover data with in situ measurements from 105 stations. This validation method ensures accuracy and reliability of snow cover products, particularly in high-altitude and cloud-prone regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of cloud blockage in optical snow cover products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Cloud blockage greatly limits the application of optical snow cover products because clouds obscure the view of the Earth's surface, preventing accurate snow cover mapping. This is a particular challenge for MODIS Terra–Aqua products, which rely on optical sensors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the IMS data overestimate snow-covered area (SCA) in certain conditions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The IMS could overestimate SCA due to poor identification of fractal snow cover. The coarse spatial resolution of passive microwave snow products relative to moderate- and high-resolution MODIS and Landsat images can lead to misinterpretations, particularly in areas with complex or irregular snow cover patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the improved snow mapping performance of the TAI algorithm compared to individual MODIS products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The TAI algorithm shows improved snow mapping performance because it combines MODIS Terra and Aqua data with IMS data, effectively removing cloud cover and enhancing resolution. This integration provides a daily cloud-free snow cover product with higher accuracy, as demonstrated by its 94% overall accuracy compared to the lower accuracy of individual MODIS Terra and Aqua products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating data from multiple sources like MODIS Terra, Aqua, and IMS for cloud-free snow cover mapping over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating data from multiple sources such as MODIS Terra, Aqua, and IMS leads to the development of a cloud-free snow cover product with significantly higher accuracy. Specifically, it results in a higher overall accuracy of 94% compared to individual MODIS products and a more extensive snow-covered area estimation of 19.1% over the Tibetan Plateau due to improved cloud removal.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of a priority scheme in merging daily MODIS Terra–Aqua images affect the accuracy of snow cover mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a priority scheme in merging daily MODIS Terra–Aqua images can enhance the accuracy of snow cover mapping by systematically prioritizing and combining data, which helps reduce errors and data gaps caused by different viewing geometries. This approach contributes to achieving a higher accuracy in the resulting snow cover product.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing a daily cloud-free snow cover product using a combination of MODIS Terra, Aqua, and IMS data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to produce a daily cloud-free snow cover product with high spatial resolution (500 m) that significantly improves the accuracy of snow cover mapping over the Tibetan Plateau, overcoming the limitations posed by cloud blockage in traditional optical remote sensing products like MODIS.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the potential benefits of addressing cloud blockage in optical snow cover products for monitoring snow-covered areas in high-altitude regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing cloud blockage in optical snow cover products allows for more accurate estimation of snow-covered areas, which is vital for understanding the water budgets in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau, ultimately supporting water resource management and climate studies in Asia's major river basins.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can cloud obstruction be effectively reduced in snow cover data collection to improve the accuracy of snow-covered area mapping in high-altitude regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Cloud obstruction can be reduced by combining MODIS Terra and Aqua data using a priority scheme to form daily merged images. Additionally, integrating the resampled IMS data with MODIS Terra-Aqua using a composite rule where remaining cloud pixels are replaced with IMS values helps achieve a cloud-free snow cover product.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What techniques are employed to ensure the spatial resolution of snow cover datasets is optimal for accurate snow depth assessment in the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The spatial resolution is optimized by resampling IMS data from 4 km to 500 m to match the resolution of MODIS Terra-Aqua, thereby enhancing the detail in the snow cover product. This approach allows for effective snow depth assessment by integrating higher resolution data from different sources.

Enablement.Question: What combination of remote sensing technologies enables the development of daily cloud-free snow cover products in high-altitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: The combination of MODIS Terra and Aqua (500 m) with the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS; 4 km) enables the development of a daily cloud-free snow cover product (500 m) for high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: How does resampling spatial resolution from different datasets contribute to generating high-resolution snow cover maps?
Enablement.Answer: Resampling the IMS data from 4 km to 500 m allows it to be integrated with the daily merged MODIS Terra–Aqua data, contributing to the generation of high-resolution snow cover maps.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods improve the accuracy of snow cover mapping over complex terrains such as the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Combining daily MODIS Terra and Aqua snow products with IMS data, using a priority scheme to merge Terra–Aqua images and replace cloud pixels with IMS pixel values, improves the accuracy of snow cover mapping over complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might cloud coverage pose a significant challenge in the accurate mapping of snow-covered areas using remote sensing technologies?
Expectation.Answer: Cloud blockage greatly limits the application of optical snow cover products, as clouds can obscure the surface, preventing accurate data collection and analysis of snow-covered areas.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of passive microwave sensors be considered advantageous in the collection of snow cover data, despite their lower spatial resolution compared to optical sensors?
Expectation.Answer: Passive microwave sensors can penetrate cloud cover, providing cloud-free snow cover products, which is a significant advantage in regions with frequent cloud coverage, despite their coarser spatial resolution compared to sensors like MODIS.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of combining multiple remote sensing data sources to enhance the resolution and accuracy of snow cover mapping on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The combination of MODIS Terra and Aqua with the IMS data has proven highly effective. The resulting TAI product offers a significantly higher accuracy of 94% compared to the original MODIS products, which are hampered by cloud coverage. The merging process also increases the detectable snow-covered area from 4.7%–8.1% to 19.1%, demonstrating its capability to mitigate cloud obscuration issues.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the challenges faced in improving snow cover detection accuracy amidst cloud coverage, and how do current methodologies address these challenges?
Judgmental.Answer: Cloud coverage is a major obstacle in optical remote sensing for snow cover detection, as it blocks the view of the ground. Current methodologies, like the TAI, address these challenges by integrating data from different satellite sources, which allow for cloud-free mapping. Prioritizing available data and using blending techniques help expose snow cover pixels despite cloud presence, although challenges remain with the spatial resolution of different datasets.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how could further improvements in data collection and integration techniques impact the future development of snow cover products?
Judgmental.Answer: Further improvements in data collection and integration could lead to even higher accuracy and resolution of snow cover products. Enhanced algorithms that better handle cloud coverage and refine spatial resolution would be beneficial. Additionally, integrating more diverse datasets, such as employing higher-resolution optical and microwave sensors, could improve snow cover detection under various atmospheric conditions, leading to more reliable water resource management in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can achieve cloud-free snow cover mapping with improved accuracy on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset achieves cloud-free snow cover mapping by combining MODIS Terra and Aqua products with the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS), which allows for the removal of cloud cover and improves snow cover mapping accuracy. The TAI algorithm resamples the IMS data to a finer resolution and integrates it with MODIS Terra-Aqua data to produce a daily cloud-free snow cover product at 500 m resolution. This approach significantly reduces cloud blockage and enhances snow cover detection.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how challenges like cloud blockage and low spatial resolution are addressed in data collection methods for snow cover on the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges like cloud blockage are addressed by developing a composite rule where remaining cloud pixels in Terra-Aqua images are replaced with IMS pixel values. The IMS data is resampled from 4 km to 500 m resolution to match the MODIS data, allowing for more detailed snow cover mapping. This combination mitigates the issue of cloud interference and enhances spatial resolution, providing more accurate snow cover data.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how the accuracy of snow cover products is validated using ground station data.
Assertion.Answer: The accuracy of snow cover products is validated using daily in situ measurements of snow depth from 105 China Meteorological Data (CMA) climate stations. The TAI product's performance is compared with station-based snow depth measurements, showing an overall accuracy of 94% in all-sky conditions. This validation method demonstrates the TAI product's significant improvement over original MODIS products, which have lower accuracy due to cloud obstruction.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to develop a cloud-free daily snow cover product for the Tibetan Plateau, highlighting any integration of different remote sensing technologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve using MODIS Terra and Aqua (500 m) combined with the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS; 4 km). The IMS data are resampled to match the MODIS resolution. The integration involves a priority scheme where cloud pixels in Terra–Aqua images are replaced with IMS values, creating a daily cloud-free snow cover product.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in using optical remote sensing for snow cover mapping on high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau, and discuss any strategies implemented to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in optical remote sensing for snow cover mapping include cloud blockage and low temporal resolution, which limits application. Strategies to overcome these include developing a daily combined Terra–Aqua–IMS (TAI) product that replaces cloud-covered pixels with data from the IMS, thus reducing cloud obscuration and improving the accuracy of snow cover mapping.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could complement the existing snow cover datasets to enhance the accuracy and resolution of snow mapping on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could complement the existing snow cover datasets include in situ measurements of snow depth from climate stations and other remote sensing data with different sensors or wavelengths that could provide additional information to improve spatial resolution and accuracy of snow mapping efforts.
